Having said so much of these matters, we pray that we may have grace from both the gods and the heroes for our speech.

Now the reason why those of the Egyptians whom I have mentioned do not sacrifice goatsâ female or male, is this:ââthe Mendesians count Pan to be one of the eight gods (now these eight gods they say came into being be- fore the twelve gods), and the painters and image-makers represent in painting and in sculpture the figure of Pan, just as the Hellenes do, with goatâs face and legs, not supposing him to be really like this but to resemble the other godsÍ¾ the cause however why they represent him in this form I prefer not to say. The Mendesians then reverence all goats and the males more than the females (and the goatherds too have greater honour than other herdsmen), but of the goats one especially is reverenced, and when he dies there is great mourning in all the Mende- sian district: and both the goat and Pan are called in the Egyptian tongue Mendes. Moreover in my lifetime there happened in that district this marvel, that is to say a he-goat had intercourse with a woman publiclyâ and this was so done that all men might have evidence of it.

The pig is accounted by the Egyptians an abominable animalÍ¾ and first, it' any of them in passing by touch a pig, he goes into the river and dips himself forthwith in the water together with his garmentsÍ¾ and then too swine- herds, though they be native Egyptians, unlike all others do not enter any of the temples in Egypt, nor is anyone willing to give his daughter in marriage to one of them or to take a wife from among themÍ¾ but the swineherds both give in marriage to one another and take from one another.
